=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame
  SpriteSet
    floor > Immovable randomtiling=0.9 img=oryx/floor3 hidden=True
    goal  > Door color=GREEN img=oryx/doorclosed1
    key   > Immovable color=ORANGE img=oryx/key2
    sword > OrientedFlicker limit=5 singleton=True img=oryx/slash1
    movable >
      avatar  > ShootAvatar   stype=sword frameRate=8
        nokey   > img=oryx/swordman1
        withkey > color=ORANGE img=oryx/swordmankey1
      enemy >  
        monsterQuick > RandomNPC cooldown=2 cons=6 img=oryx/bat1
        monsterNormal > RandomNPC cooldown=4 cons=8 img=oryx/spider2
        monsterSlow > RandomNPC cooldown=8 cons=12 img=oryx/scorpion1
      wall > Immovable autotiling=true img=oryx/wall3
      	

  LevelMapping
    g > floor goal
    + > floor key        
    A > floor nokey
    1 > floor monsterQuick
    2 > floor monsterNormal
    3 > floor monsterSlow
    w > wall
    . > floor
    

  InteractionSet
    movable wall  > stepBack
    nokey goal    > stepBack
    goal withkey  > killSprite scoreChange=1
    enemy sword > killSprite scoreChange=2
    enemy enemy > stepBack
    avatar enemy > killSprite scoreChange=-1
    nokey key     > transformTo stype=withkey scoreChange=1 killSecond=True

  TerminationSet
    SpriteCounter stype=goal   win=True
    SpriteCounter stype=avatar win=False
This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Below is an analysis of the game based on the provided rules:

────────────────────────
1. Game Genre

• Action–Puzzle / Maze Adventure  
 – The game is played on a grid‐ or tile–based level (note the level layout with walls, floors, doors, keys, etc.).  
 – It combines real–time movement and combat (with the “sword” mechanic and various enemy NPCs) with puzzle elements (navigating a maze, collecting a key, and unlocking a door).

────────────────────────
2. Mechanics

• Sprite Types and Their Roles  
 – Floor: Background element (hidden and decorative).  
 – Wall: Immovable and autotiled barriers, forming the maze’s structure.  
 – Avatar: The player–controlled character (in this case, represented by an “A” in the layout) that can shoot a “sword” (an oriented flicker sprite used as an attack mechanism).  
 – Nokey and Withkey: Two states for the player character. Initially, the avatar likely acts as “nokey” and, upon interacting with a key, transforms into “withkey” (via the interaction “nokey key > transformTo stype=withkey”).  
 – Key: An immovable object (colored orange) that, when touched by a “nokey” sprite, transforms it into one that carries the key (“withkey”).  
 – Goal: Represented by a green door; interacting with it while possessing the key (i.e. the sprite “withkey”) triggers the door’s removal (“goal withkey > killSprite”) and a score gain.  
 – Sword: A short–lived attack sprite which “shoots” from the avatar and can kill enemies.  
 – Enemy: Several types of enemies (monsterQuick, monsterNormal, monsterSlow) move randomly with varying cooldowns and “cons” (a possible measure of their speed or persistence).  
 – Movable: Likely represents objects that can be pushed around (though only one interaction is defined with wall objects).

• Interactions  
 – Physical contact with certain objects can push the player/colliding sprite back (“stepBack”), enforcing movement restrictions (e.g., trying to push through walls or a locked door without the key).  
 – Collecting the key automatically transforms a “nokey” sprite to “withkey”, adding to the score.  
 – When a “withkey” sprite touches the goal, the door “dies” (is removed) and the player gains score.  
 – The sword can be used against enemies (each enemy killed by the sword increases score by 2).  
 – In direct collision with an enemy, the avatar suffers by having the enemy killed but at the expense of a score penalty (–1).

• Level Layout  
 – A bordered maze made of walls with open spaces, scattered with various symbols.  
 – “A” most likely represents the avatar’s starting position.  
 – Numbers (such as “1”, “2”, “3”) are traditionally used in these systems to denote different enemy types (monsterSlow, monsterNormal, monsterQuick, etc.) or possibly other interactive elements.  
 – The “+” might denote the key’s location, and “g” is likely the goal (the green door).

────────────────────────
3. Objective

• Primary Goal  
 – The player must navigate the maze, avoid or manage enemies, collect the key (transforming the avatar from “nokey” to “withkey”), and then reach (and interact with) the goal (the door).

• Score Incentives  
 – Collecting key and then unlocking the door increases the score (each awarding +1).  
 – Killing enemies with the sword provides additional points (+2 per enemy), while colliding directly with an enemy results in a penalty (–1).

────────────────────────
4. Win/Loss Conditions

• Winning  
 – The termination condition “SpriteCounter stype=goal win=True” indicates that if the goal sprite is removed (killed via interaction with a “withkey” sprite) then the player wins. In effect, successfully reaching the goal with the key ends the level in victory.

• Losing  
 – The termination condition “SpriteCounter stype=avatar win=False” means that if the player’s avatar is eliminated (e.g., through enemy collisions or possibly other hazards), the game is lost. Moves/actions that result in the avatar’s removal or death thus lead to loss.

────────────────────────
5. Overall Strategy

• Route Planning and Timing  
 – Study the maze layout to determine the optimal path from your starting point to the key, and then from the key to the goal.  
 – Time your movements to avoid encounters with the roaming enemies, especially the faster ones (monsterQuick).

• Key Collection  
 – Make the collection of the key a priority early in the level since unlocking and winning depend on transforming your state to “withkey”.  
 – Avoid unnecessary combat when collecting the key; if timed properly, you can slip past enemy patrols.

• Combat Tactics  
 – Use the sword attack judiciously to clear enemies that block your optimal path. The sword has a limit on its striking ability (“limit=5”) and a set frame rate (frameRate=8), so learn its timing and effective range.  
 – Remember that while using the sword gives a scoring bonus, colliding with enemies directly will penalize you.  

• Avoiding Hazards  
 – Follow the “stepBack” interactions: if you run into walls or try to engage the locked door without the key, you’ll be pushed back, so understand these boundaries to plan your moves.  
 – Manage your encounters with enemies; sometimes it’s better to dodge rather than attack, especially if you’re not in possession of the key yet.

• Score Maximization  
 – In addition to simply reaching the goal, you can improve your score by eliminating enemies with your sword when the opportunity arises, but balance this with the need to avoid damage.
  
────────────────────────
Summary

The game is a maze-based action puzzle in which you must navigate a level filled with walls and roaming enemies. Your objective is to first collect the key (transforming your character to “withkey”), then reach and “unlock” the door (goal) to win. Along the way, you can use your sword to eliminate enemies and earn extra points, but be careful: direct contact with enemies without using your weapon results in a score penalty and could eventually lead to your avatar’s death. The overall strategy is to carefully plan your route and timings, secure the key early, and cautiously engage or avoid enemies on your way to the goal.

This analysis should help in understanding the game’s design, objectives, and how to approach playing it effectively.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
